reviewText:
When I bought the game it looked like a normal pc game with support for VR on the steam store page, but it acctualy is a VR ONLY game. If you don't have VR you cant play the game.... I myself dont have a VR device, so i had to refund the game.. I wish they would make it more easier to see if its a VR only game etc in the future on steam. Anyways cant really review the game so this is more of an warning to others who dont have VR who want to play this game.


edit: They updated store page with a tiny vr only" in the description."

reviewText:
EDIT:  For those of you pointing out that I only have an hour of gameplay - I have completed 2/4 of the jobs offered, so roughly half of the scripted gameplay.

Oh, Job Simulator...  I wish I could enjoy you.  I can see the appeal, don't get me wrong, but as an avid gamer it just doesn't really do anything for me - even viewing it purely as an experience, I couldn't get into it.  I appreciate the humor, the attention to detail, the heart, but...  it just doesn't hold my attention, even compared to other experiences.  If it were $5, even $10, I could see myself recommending it as an intro to VR" type experience.

I think the real issue is that the world doesn't respond to your decisions whatsoever.  The game comes down to "here's a simple task
date: now do whatever you want to do
recommended: and the game will move onto another task."  From what I can tell
hoursPlayed: the game plays out the same no matter what you do. Let's say it asks you to make a sandwich and you make it out of uncooked bacon
voteText: an apple and a CD-Rom and then serve it up... the game moves onto the next task.  Whoopie
helpfulPercent: CD-Rom sandwich and no one cares.  Hilarious the first few times
votesHelpful: especially with some friends in the room
votesFunny: it just gets stale.\n\nTL;DR:  Good for intro VR
column16: but your (often funny) decisions are meaningless and the world is unresponsive to them. It's probably not worth the price.\n\nThat's my two cents."

reviewText:
The year is 2050. You are a human simulating the most boring jobs of the 21st century in a museum based on the warped history of your robot overlords.

The inaccuracies between reality and the job simulator are often satirical or just silly (like having to change headlight fluid as a mechanic.) The humor and polish are very reminiscent of a Valve game. While it may not blow you away, it is extremely accessible and is a suprisingly fun social game.

Pros:Very well polished.
Comes with four complete jobs: Office Worker, Gourmet Chef, Store Clerk, and Auto Mechanic.
Dialog with robot customers and coworkers is often comical.
Gags and pop culture references EVERYWHERE.
Given that there is no locomotion they make excellent use of the space your are given. Example: When you're a chef you can flip a switch to replace your sink with a blender or a microwave.
Kid Friendly.
Fantasic demo game for people new to VR.
Consistent 90fps, one of the most stable VR games I've played. Especially considering how nice it looks.
As I said earlier a suprisingly good social game. When you have one person playing and have some people on the couch something magical happens. Observers heckle/shout out commands, laughing at the goofy interactions of the player - it's a good time all around.
Neutral:By it's nature all tasks are extremely simple.
I can imagine you'd run into issues if you had a smaller than average play space, but that's not the games fault.
Cons:Once you've played through each of the jobs there is little replayability. Unless you count laughing at other people playing it.
Feels like an extended demo rather than a full game, however, even at $30 I'd probably recommend it. (If HTC were to discontinue it being bundled with the Vive in the future.) While $30 is steep for the time it takes to beat, I'd say it's roughly on par with the rest of the VR catalog, as generally most games are overpriced. Which again, makes sense given the relatively small playerbase.
Rig: Intel Core i7-5930K, 32GB DDR4 2800, (x2) EVGA GTX 980 SC (One card dedicated to PhysX), 500GB Samsung 840 Evo SSD, Win 10.

reviewText: This is the experience you can hand to people who don't play video games normally and haven't been following VR at all and they will instantly become a beliver in room scale motion-tracked virtual reality. reviewText:
If you are going to show off your Vive to someone this is great game to do it.  Easy to play and loads of funny moments.  It was also great to find a Rick and Morty easter eggs in the game.  Hopefully they add more than the 4 jobs but even with those you can have many hours of game play.

It is so immersive that I actually dropped my controllers a number of times trying to place them on a counter.  I also tried to lean on a wall that wasn't there (for the record i stayed on my feet).

Favorite moment: pouring mustard into a customer's pipe.

I ran into a few minor bugs that required a reset but i'm sure they will be iron out in future updates.

reviewText:
Considering this game was free with my VIve I will not be putting price into consideration. I also think current price is inflated.

At first glance this seemed like a lame game with very little content. After giving it a fair shot I quickly came to enjoy the huge amount of personality in this game. The defining feature and i think main selling point is  how interactive it is. If you see an object  and think it does something chances are it does. You can mess with everything in the game and they make sure to saturate every sim with tons of little things to play with.

Hats off to the developers for jam packing this game with quirky robots  and  doodads.

reviewText:
This is one of the flagship games for the Vive. A hilariously rich environment offers a playground for your imagination. You can trust that the objects you want to interact with are full of possibility. The writing and product design in the game is just as funny as Justin Roilands improvised humor. It's as good as a party game as an individual experience. I've only logged an hour and feel like there will still be replayability.

This game is a MUST HAVE...and of course you do if you bought a Vive.

Any trust you place in this game is well placed as long as you have a Vive headset to play it on! (Seriously, don't buy this if you don't have a Vive.)

reviewText:
I thought that Job Simulator would be just a good demo to VR, and some funny interactions. It turns out that it's my children's (ages 8, 11, 12) favorite game and the one they go back to every single day. Who figured they would like to Job so much at such a young age.

For those of us adults, this game really is one of the best introductions to VR to play in a room with other people, and while the replay value isn't as great for us, the party aspects when you have a second monitor hooked up and an audience is really funny.

This is a great game. And I hope they add a few extra environments over the next few months. Humor, characters and the story" are perfectly done for this kind of game.

5/5. Family favorite game. 2nd only to tilt brush"

reviewText:
I just got my Vive yesterday and set it up. Got up an hour and a half early this morning. I wanted to play something before my kids woke up. I have been waiting to try this game, espeically once I knew it was bundled in. Honestly after doing the office level, I'm pretty happy with it. Now for the good and bad, because reviews need constructive criticism. :)

Good:
- Funny and charming
- Unique idea
- Controls are very intuitive
- Great title to show off VR

Bad:
- A bit short
- Cost if you didn't get bundle

Overall it is a great game. Fun and entertaining. It is a good game to get people aquainted with VR. It is a bit on the short  side. I spent 30 minutes playing around in the office and completing objectives. The whole game is likely only 3 - 4 hours of content for most people.  The cost is a bit high for the amount of time an indiviual may spend playing, but this is also one of the first games for consumer VR. Hopefully they do add a few more jobs to extend it a little more, otherwise this game is great!

reviewText: Job Simulator is the most polished and fluid game I have played for the Vive (out of ~25 games). Its quirky style and polish will have you immersed quickly. If you are anything like me, you won't be able to resist waving and/or throwing things at the many NPCs. The attention to detail and ability to do lots of unexpected functions will not stop making me smile.\n\nThat being said, I cannot see myself getting more than 10-15 hours of gameplay out of this title. I enjoy showing it to friends and family, would gladly pay the $30 if it had not come with my Vive, but would be even more excited to see what the developers could do creating content with more replay value.

reviewText:
======================================
(First Impressions) - Job Simulator
======================================

Video - https://youtu.be/BndklhqtwtU

**Gameplay/My Experience**

I start things off in a large white room greeted by friendly robots instructing me about where I am. Job Simulator is based on the idea that all mankind has died many years ago and now robots rule the world. I am visiting this place to experience the everyday jobs of the previous humans of the past.

On the table in front of me is a tray of video game cartridge shaped objects with job titles on them, I take the first one Office Worker" and toss it into the machine. I'm now transported to an office and inside a worker's cubicle. I am surrounded by all the common things an office might have like computers
recommended: staplers and such. I am then greeted by a robot who informs me that humans in this time liked to eat lots doughnuts and sugar filled coffee's prior to a work day.\n\nA cart appears with a box of doughnuts and coffee mugs
hoursPlayed: I am able to open the box grab a doughnut pull it do my face and experience a satisfying chomp out of it. Naturally I begin to grab them with both hands quickly chomping away the whole box in seconds. Next I take the coffee mug and fill it with creamer
voteText: sugar and lots of coffee so much that it overflows and spills everywhere.\n\nI begin grabbing random items off the desk such as the stapler that allows you to fire staples in a gun like fashion or the copy machine which ironically lets you copy whole objects like plants or multiple staplers for duel wielding fun. You can interact with the computer
helpfulPercent: painting or even making a power point presentation for a future mission. The office worker is jam packed with over 1.5+ hours worth of missions and tons of fun things to mess with.\n\nI head back to the main games lobby via summoning a briefcase and eating the "really" burrito
votesHelpful: very creative concept. Next I choose the chef worker which allows me to prepare food for hungry customers. You can make bizarre sandwiches create a variety of soups mixing ingredients in a large stove top pot. The missions are fun and get you to explore almost every single aspect of the cooking area. Feel like juggling tomatoes? want to make a nuclear tea? feel like making a wine steak burnt toast omelet sandwich? or maybe you just enjoy listening to music and tossing random items into the piranha tank across the hall to be chipped? whatever it is your looking to mess around with in a kitchen this has it.\n\nThe other two jobs were auto mechanic and store clerk. As a clerk I was able to serve my "happy" customers by providing them with common store items they asked for. I was able to ring up items multiple times
commentsCount: throw things at them. Basically do everything you ever wanted to do as a fed up person in customer service. Moving onto the auto mechanic you take on the roll of a swindly mechanic fixing clients cars as they arrive at your garage. pull apart the cars and give them cheap parts to save a buck
column16: replace the battery with a potato
column17: fill the gas tank with hot sauce
column18:
attempt to throw a Frisbee out the garage door at passing cars. The sky is the limit in all these jobs and it truly is a blast interacting with objects in the environment.

==================================================

** Graphics/Audio **

Simple cartoon style graphics are pleasantly used in this game and give your a fun feeling and care free experience. Objects are all very intractable and well detailed for the way they function. I was constantly testing things to see if they would react the way my mind assumed they would and sure enough they did exactly what I imagined very pleased with that.

The audio is also very good
column19:
its comedic and the sound effects are very cartoon-esk loud drippy sounds from pouring liquid and bonk and smash sounds from breaking and throwing objects. The robots speaking is also a great laugh going from a random smooth talking to a monotone inserted statement really brings up some great humor filled moments.

==================================================

**VR/Comfort**

I have only experienced a few tracking issues as others have had at the time of this review
column20: but for the most part the game is exceptionally accurate in the tracking. I am easily able to toss objects in the air and catch them with the other hand. Moving around the room feels great and unhindered by any design issues.\n\nThere were no moments of sickness or uncomfortable feelings throughout my 5 hours of playing this title so far
column21:
very smooth and very well designed for VR.

==================================================

**My Wishlist**

I'm really hoping for more experiences to come soon
column23: more ideas to keep me invested in the game.\n\nI would really like to see some sort of multiplayer implemented in the future
column24:
and perhaps co op games where you would have to work together to prepare a meal or perform a task.

==================================================
"

reviewText:
I was skeptical at first: why would I want to simulate jobs when I already have a job?

Then I gave it a try nevertheless, and it turns out to be a great game!

The scenario is that robots rule the world, and as a human who doesn’t need to work, you go to a museum where robots show you how having a job used to be. The fact that the robots often don’t quite grasp how things actually were makes for funny cutscenes.

Further, all the jobs contain a lot of loving detail and (to me) unexpected humour. As an example, as a car mechanic, one of your tasks is to sabotage a customer’s car as per SlzBot’s (Sleaze-Bot, your boss) instructions.

I spent a few hours in this and haven’t yet explored all jobs there are. Greatly recommended!

reviewText: As a newcomer to the whole VR world, this game is great at introducing you to it. It is an incredibly intuitive game to play, and the game never gets stale, as there is always something going on either in the foreground or the background. Another thing to note is the attention to detail! You see a copying machine, and because your butt isn´t virtual yet, you try it with your hands, and it works! You get virtual printouts of your virtual hands! ( I am starting to ramble aren´t I?) This game is in my opinion a must have for everyone getting into VR or as a showcase for friends to introduce them to VR. The only thing I find really regrettable is the hefty price-point of this game. I get, that an enormous amount of work went into it, but you just burn through the 4 available jobs which you can partake in, even more so, when there is The Lab, where you get more diversity, an equal amount of play time for free... Don´t get me wrong, this game deserves every credits it gets, evenmore so because it runs brilliantly without any issues on my more or less mediocre Pc, it´s just too expensive. TL:Dr If you have the money, get this game, if you don´t, maybe opt for games like Audioshield or Hover Junkers, as you get longer enjoyment out of those games.

reviewText: Job Simulator is a game that I think is worth trying, but not at $40 or even its now lowered $30 price tag. It's not a bad game, and it has a few hours of amusement in it, but the fun of it comes more from interacting with the various items in each stage than actually doing the jobs most of the time. It's more of a novelty than a game, and while there's nothing wrong with that and it does a great job of doing it, I don't think it's priced to reflect that. If you get the game for free in the bundle you get when you currently buy a Vive then it's definitely worth playing, and I would definitely recommend it, but I don't think it's worth buying separately.

reviewText:
A fun, clean demonstration of what VR can do.

The game is clearly very cleverly designed to maximize what you can do - most sections are laid out so you never have to turn a full 360 degrees ( though you are capable of it), meaning you won't have to step over your chord. The game is fun and quirky, and easy for people of all ages to jump into and enjoy.

This game is a posterchild of what VR and the HTC Vive do, and for good reason.

reviewText:
This is one of the games that I actually spent the most amount of time with, and the one singular game that I think demonstrates all of the strengths of the platform. I think it’s a great tutorial to VR, even though I’m not super compelled to return to it.

The conceit is simple: you’re a robot, doing jobs that robots think humans did! But underneath that surface, it’s actually even simpler: play. Play with the coffee machine. Play with the CDs. Play with the buttons. Everything that seems interactable is interactable. Throw things at robots. Drink the wine. Burn the toast. Use your hands to do things that you would do. Realize they are slightly clumsier than you are used to and that you will burn the tea.  Do the thing. Do anything.

Like I said, it’s an incredible introduction into VR -- but after a while, you do wonder why you're doing the things you're doing. That's fine! That means it's time to move on to the other games and experiences.

reviewText: Very intuitive and creative, with an excellent sense of humor and astounding attention to detail. reviewText:
This game isn't bad. It's just that it feels like one of those games in Elementary school that kids play to learn basic computer skills or general math problems. I got this game with my VIve, but if I had to pay for it, I'd say $5 is top that I'd pay for it. Each job is 30-45 minutes tops. Game play is simply pick up X item and put it Y.

It's a great game to teach a child the basics of VR, but as an adult, it's rather lack luster. I can only pick up so many X items and put it Y until it feels like playing with that square box with the holes that match the shapes of blocks.

Like I said, it's not a bad game, it's just the entertainment to price is way off. Just look at all the people that reviewed this game, half of them make it to 4 hours of play. I'm putting my money on 80% of the people with more than 6 hours had multiple people play it since the code you get for the game is good for one steam account.
voteText: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
First off: This comes free with the Vive. I would not recommend getting this game for full price if you don't get it for free.

I am not saying it is a bad game but it gets old very fast. It's not like you can play this for 10 hours and still have fun like on the first day. There are four levels, each of them have different challenges (make a hotdog, make some tea, look at the resumes and hire someone,...) that keep you busy while you destroy your surroundings because you are a clumsy motherfu cker.

The levels adjust to your room size so you might encounter a different layout than you see on videos/online. The writing is great and at times really funny. But that doesn't hide the fact that this game does not have much replayability. I believe it is a great demo game, to show VR to a bunch of friends.

Still I think it is a good game, just not worth the price they ask for. But I got it for free with my Vive, so I can't complain too much :P

reviewText:
It's a tough one. Okay free game, certainly not worth retail price.

Pros:
All the little interaction details have been addressed in this game, so interaction with everything is as it seems. A lot of games have left out this attention to detail and it really kills the immersion.
Some of the humour is great.

Cons:

reviewText: Product received for free\n\nIt's really no more than a physics sandbox. Don't take me wrong - the game is pretty fun if you have at least a sliver of imagination. It's definitely a great way of introducing the concept of VR to your friends and family. The problem is that it's very short (4 jobs, each takes 10-30 minutes to complete, depending on how much you screw around) and has practically no replayability. That would be fine if it wasn't for it's price (£22.99 at the time of the review). The only reason I own it is because it came free with the Vive - I'd definitely not recommend it at full price.

reviewText: If you bought a Vive early and are eligible for this game free of charge, then by all means try this. It is a fun introduction to VR with occasional funny writing and a good level of interactivity. But I could not recommend paying anything more than about $5 for this title. It is certainly a novel experience but once you have tried it once there is no reason to try it again. It has neither the structured gameplay to call it a game, or the variability or flexibility to call it a sandbox. It will last you an hour at most and afterwards you will either want to delete it from your hard drive, or keep it around purely for demoing to others.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Seems to be a fun and comical game, but unfortunately not playable if you do not have a recent iteration of an Intel processor. My rig's got an i5-2500k OC'ed to 4.2Ghz (temperature at constant 56°C), 32GB Ram and a 980TI, so it should run this game somewhat decent. Unfortunately, it doesn't. Now before anyone complains that my CPU's too slow, it shouldn't be. This game uses just a constant 50-60% of all 4 cores, with 1 core pushing to 90% about every 5 seconds (garbage collector?). GPU isn't even anywhere near stressed, sitting at 18-25%.

Yet, the game is stuttering permanently - missing frames constantly. No such problems with other VR games, and the proposed fixes by the developers have not caused the stutter to go away.

Will try again if an update is released, but for now, I can't give this game a good recommendation due to it's performance problems.

reviewText:
While this game is hilarious, creative, and very intuitive, I simply cannot recommend a 37€ game that offers only 3 hours of gameplay. This might be one of the best games to demo the Vive with, but once you've finished all the jobs there are, there's very little reason to continue playing.

I would recommend this game if it got a hefty price cut, or if many more jobs were added for you to have fun in. Perhaps a few new gamemodes would give you more reasons to continue playing?

tldr; Great game, creative concept, but far too short and expensive for what it is.

reviewText:
frame rate drops in most scene( i5+970 ), harvy VR sickness.


There are 4 jobs in this game, each one is like 40min long.
I played 2 out of 4, spent 88min , and had sickness for over an hour.

It was really fun.

When I was in the game, i was really enjoying it, but the frame rate problem always took me me back to the reality.

And the game's page suggests an i5+970 will do, but i think that's not enough.

so, to those who has better hardware than an i5+970, this game is a thumbs up.

but for me it is 5/10.

reviewText:
Great game, love the humor :)
used this to demo VR to a bunch of people, a lot of them have problems understanding what theyre supposed to do at times, so you need to guide them a bit, but its a lot of fun :)

there doesnt seem to be a way toexit the game, or any of the simulations,, at all?
there are quite some glitches with the physics as well, but nothing major.

there are no highscore or challange modes a la space pirate trainer, so i think the replay value is pretty low.
And there arent to many missions" or levels
date: youll finish it all in a week
recommended:
possibly less.
So id consider this more of an elaborate tech demo and not really a full game.

Still one of the best vr experiences right now
hoursPlayed: so id definitely recommend it!\nIf you dont get it for free

reviewText:
This game is a lot of fun, but not very much replay value.

still fun though :D
